column27: issues with safeguarding and routine for less independent student
A great idea, but difficult to implement

It is my opinion that whilst the opportunity of 1 day out the school building per week would highly benefit staff who don’t need to travel and can work from home, I don’t think KS3 or KS4 students would really see that time as valuable time to study, rather an extra weekend day to go and relax. It could be directed work time with set work from teachers, but does that defeat the purpose of giving teachers a day to catch up, and do students have the equipment or workspace to do that at home?
If this doesn’t affect teachers salary will be great. How does it affect salary of administration.?

National curriculum is tight enough as it is in terms of having enough teaching time to teach the full curriculum in a five day week to GCSE pupils. A four day week would reduce that time further unless the national curriculum is reduced in terms of content or level of assessment
Efficiency and productivity could be increased
As most parents work this has to be wider programme than just schools. FSM and support of most disadvantaged students could be a big draw back even through it is a big plus for teachers!
I have seen 4 day weeks offered in some schools for staff, while the school operates on a 5 day week! The benefits seem enormous.
